value.title: 9th grade students make wigs from pineapple leaves for cancer patients
value.body:
Two ninth-grade students from central Vietnam, Tran Nguyen An Hoa and Tran Thien Thao, won second prize at the Khanh Hoa Province Sci-tech Competition for creating synthetic hair from discarded pineapple leaves. Their project was inspired by seeing piles of pineapple leaves being burned in Ninh Tay Commune. With their teacher's guidance, they experimented with the strong and durable fibers of the leaves, creating wigs that were soft, natural, and heat-resistant.

The students collected and processed 55 kg of pineapple leaves, extracting fibers which were dyed using organic materials. After testing the fibers for safety and ensuring they contained no harmful substances, they assembled the wigs by hand. The first wig was donated to a cancer patient, and they received praise for their innovative approach to sustainable production and helping cancer patients feel more confident. Their project exemplified applying science to real-world problems and environmental consciousness.

value.title: TasteAtlas ranks Vietnamese street foods among the best in Southeast Asia
value.body:
TasteAtlas recently ranked 26 Vietnamese street foods among the top 100 in Southeast Asia for 2025. Iconic dishes like pho and banh mi secured high spots, ranking third and ninth, respectively. Other notable Vietnamese street foods include nem lui (grilled pork sausage), banh xeo (crispy pancakes), banh beo (steamed rice cakes), and bun dau mam tom (vermicelli with tofu and shrimp paste).

Lesser-known treats such as bo bia (spring rolls with Chinese sausage), banh ran (glutinous rice balls), and banh khot (savory mini pancakes) also made the list. These dishes, loved for their unique flavors and textures, reflect Vietnam's rich culinary tradition and are gaining recognition across Southeast Asia.

value.title: Da Lat stream at sunrise: a fairytale-like scene
value.body:
Suoi Tia, located near Da Lat, offers a stunning sunrise experience, transforming into a dreamlike scene as golden-hued trees reflect on the waters. This hidden gem, situated 12 kilometers from Da Lat, is part of the Tuyen Lam Lake's source and surrounded by rare timber trees and a diverse ecosystem.

The best time to visit is in spring, when the cho trees shed their leaves and bloom golden-orange foliage, illuminated by the sunrise. Access is challenging, keeping the area undiscovered by most tourists, but those who venture here are rewarded with breathtaking views. Travelers can take a boat ride or use a paddleboard to explore the waters, making it a perfect spot for a morning picnic.

value.title: Chinese food and beverage chains win fans in Southeast Asia
value.body:
Chinese food and beverage brands, particularly Mixue Group, are gaining popularity in Southeast Asia, challenging major American chains and expanding China's commercial and cultural influence. Mixue, which overtook Starbucks and McDonald's in store numbers, offers affordable ice cream, bubble tea, and coffee, with over 45,000 stores globally, including 6,100 in Southeast Asia. Other notable brands include Haidilao hotpot and Luckin Coffee.

Chinese F&B companies are expanding quickly due to their efficient operations and aggressive marketing strategies. They are particularly successful in countries with large Chinese-speaking populations like Malaysia and Singapore. Their affordable pricing and quick market entry contrast with Western brands, which often struggle with finding local partners and long-term planning. As these brands expand, they contribute to changing perceptions of Chinese products, from cheap goods to valuable offerings, potentially increasing China's soft power globally.

value.title: Can you lose your job for what you post on social media? Here's what the experts say
value.body:
Employees considering criticizing their employer on social media should be cautious. While there are legal protections for certain types of speech, employers generally have significant discretion to fire workers, especially under "at-will" contracts. Employees may be protected if their speech pertains to work conditions and involves engaging with coworkers, as outlined by the National Labor Relations Act. However, general criticisms like "my employer stinks" are not protected. Public sector employees enjoy additional protection under the First Amendment if their speech addresses public concerns without causing undue disruption.

Employers can limit false or defamatory statements but cannot outright ban critical posts about employment practices. Social media policies can restrict disparaging comments about products, competitors, or trade secrets. Employees who believe they've been retaliated against for protected speech can file complaints with the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB). However, such cases can be time-consuming, and employees are entitled to back pay if a judge rules in their favor.

value.title: 'Extermination' site discovered in Mexico with cremation ovens, human remains
value.body:
In Jalisco, Mexico, authorities are investigating a horrifying "extermination" site discovered by volunteers searching for missing loved ones. The site, believed to have been used by the New Generation Jalisco Cartel, contains human remains, cremation ovens, bone fragments, shoes, clothing, and children's toys. Volunteers, part of a group called "Guerreros Buscadores," were led to the Izaguirre Ranch, where they found three crematory ovens and almost 100 shell casings.

Despite a previous raid by Mexican authorities last September, the discovery of human remains was not made until this recent search. The total number of victims remains unknown, but around 700 personal items were found. This discovery highlights the ongoing issue of mass graves in Mexico, with over 120,000 people forcibly disappeared. The find has sparked outrage and calls for stronger action against cartel violence. Governor Pablo Lemus assured that his office is cooperating with federal authorities on the investigation.

value.title: Washington, DC's economy is headed for a recession as Trump slashes federal workforce
value.body:
Tyler Wolf, a former employment attorney at the US Department of Health and Human Services, was laid off amid federal job cuts led by Elon Musk's efficiency team. These layoffs are impacting Washington, DC, with economists warning that the area may slip into a recession. Wolf has adjusted his lifestyle by cutting spending and planning to move in with his parents.

The job losses, which include 103,452 federal workers nationwide, are already affecting the local economy, with businesses like Timgad Café reporting reduced foot traffic. Many workers, like Alexandra Reid, are struggling with significantly reduced household incomes and tightening their budgets.

The DC housing market is also showing signs of strain, with more homes being listed for sale. Experts predict that the full economic effects, including widespread pain for consumer-facing industries, could be felt as soon as the second half of the year.

value.title: Hundreds gather outside Tesla showrooms in backlash to Elon Musk's role with DOGE
value.body:
The "Tesla Takedown" movement, initiated by actor Alex Winter and professor Joan Donovan, is rallying against Elon Musk's involvement in U.S. government politics. Demonstrations are taking place nationwide, with over 80 protests planned for the near future, urging people to boycott Tesla, sell their vehicles, and dump stocks.

The protests, driven by Musk's federal cost-cutting role, especially in the Department of Government Efficiency, have led to multiple incidents of vandalism at Tesla locations, with police investigations ongoing.

While Musk's political role and Tesla's stock have been under pressure, the protests have attracted media attention, including a White House appearance with President Trump showcasing Tesla cars. Tesla's stock has dropped significantly, and concerns about Musk's influence may hurt the company's reputation, especially with increasing competition in the electric vehicle market. However, some protesters stress their target is Musk personally, not Tesla owners or the cars themselves.

value.title: Magnus Carlsen rules out classical World Chess Championship return, shifting focus to new era
value.body:
Magnus Carlsen, a five-time World Chess Champion, has ruled out a return to the classical World Chess Championship, citing a lack of motivation. Carlsen, who last won the title in 2021, has had a strained relationship with the International Chess Federation (FIDE) and has no plans to compete for the classical title again.

Instead, he is focusing on promoting new chess competitions, such as Freestyle and the Esports World Cup, and representing Team Liquid. Despite his disinterest in FIDE's classical championship, Carlsen remains active in the chess world, winning titles like Chess.com's Speed Chess Championship and sharing the World Blitz Championship with Ian Nepomniachtchi. Carlsen is also considering mentoring the next generation of players in the future but for now, is focused on competing and proving his continued dominance.

value.title: Rory McIlroy comfortably beats JJ Spaun in rare Monday playoff to win second Players Championship
value.body:
Rory McIlroy secured his second Players Championship title by defeating JJ Spaun in a three-hole Monday playoff at TPC Sawgrass. McIlroy finished the playoff one-over par, three shots ahead of Spaun, who struggled significantly, including hitting into water at the iconic 17th hole.

McIlroy's steady play on holes 16 and 17 contrasted Spaun's mistakes, allowing a comfortable victory despite challenging windy conditions. With this win, McIlroy becomes the first European to capture multiple Players Championships and now holds 28 PGA Tour victories. He credited his recent improvements and competitive inspiration from Scottie Scheffler's success. McIlroy's win boosts his confidence ahead of April's Masters, the only major he has yet to win.
